description: Avoid words that are subjective and cannot be measured.
good_examples: within 5 seconds
3 transactions per second
correction_strategy: Replace the vague adjective with a specific numeric metric or SLA reference.

description: Passive voice obscures who or what is performing the action.
good_examples: The System shall save the data.
The Backend Service shall generate the report.
correction_strategy: Identify the actor (System, User, Module) and make them the subject of the sentence.

good_examples: maximum of 3 clicks
consistent with Style Guide V2.0
correction_strategy: Define the constraint in verifiable terms (e.g., number of clicks, compliance with a standard).

description: Avoid combining multiple requirements into one sentence using 'and' or 'or'.
bad_examples: The system shall save the user profile and send a confirmation email.
good_examples: The system shall save the user profile.
The system shall send a confirmation email.
correction_strategy: Split the sentence into two separate atomic requirements.

description: Requirements that do not specify who or what performs the action.
good_examples: The Authentication Service shall validate user credentials during login.
The System shall encrypt all sensitive data using AES-256.
correction_strategy: Explicitly state the actor (System, User, specific component) that performs the action.

description: Unclear timing, sequence, or duration of actions.
bad_examples: The system should update the database.
Users can access reports after login.
good_examples: The system shall update the database within 100ms of receiving the transaction.
Users shall be able to access reports immediately after successful authentication.
correction_strategy: Specify exact timing (when, how long, sequence) or use precise temporal markers (immediately, within X seconds, after event Y).

description: Using domain-specific terms, acronyms, or concepts without definition.
bad_examples: The system must comply with GDPR.
The API should use RESTful principles.
good_examples: The system shall comply with GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) requirements for data privacy.
The API shall follow REST (Representational State Transfer) architectural principles with stateless communication.
correction_strategy: Define acronyms on first use, provide context for domain terms, or reference a glossary entry.

description: Unclear conditions, triggers, or circumstances under which requirement applies.
bad_examples: The system should handle errors gracefully.
good_examples: The system shall display user-friendly error messages and log technical details when any API call returns HTTP status 4xx or 5xx.
The system shall perform automated database backups daily at 2:00 AM UTC.
correction_strategy: Specify exact conditions, triggers, thresholds, or scenarios that activate the requirement.

description: Using relative terms without a baseline or reference point.
bad_examples: The new system should be faster.
good_examples: The new system shall process transactions 50% faster than the legacy system (reducing average response time from 500ms to 250ms).
The interface shall reduce the number of user actions required to complete checkout from 5 steps to 2 steps.
correction_strategy: Provide a baseline for comparison or use absolute metrics instead of relative terms.

description: Requirements that lack necessary constraints, limits, or boundaries.
bad_examples: The system should support multiple users.
The database can store user data.
good_examples: The system shall support up to 10,000 concurrent users with response time degradation not exceeding 20%.
The database shall store user profile data with a maximum record size of 5MB per user.
correction_strategy: Add explicit constraints: maximum values, limits, boundaries, or acceptable ranges.

description: Unclear what parts of the system or which components are affected.
good_examples: The Authentication Module shall implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all admin accounts.
The Search Service shall return results within 200ms for queries on datasets up to 1 million records.
correction_strategy: Specify the exact component, module, feature, or subsystem to which the requirement applies.

description: Using weak modal verbs (should, could, might) instead of mandatory language (shall, must).
good_examples: The system shall validate all user input before processing.
The system shall enable authenticated users to export their data in CSV format.
correction_strategy: Use 'shall' for mandatory requirements, 'should' only for recommendations, and 'may' for optional features.

description: Requirements that don't specify behavior under error or exception conditions.
good_examples: The system shall process payments and, if payment fails, shall display error code P001 and log the transaction attempt.
Users shall be able to upload files up to 10MB; if upload fails, the system shall display a specific error message and allow retry.
correction_strategy: Explicitly state what happens in error cases, timeouts, or exception scenarios.

description: Unclear which user roles or personas the requirement applies to.
good_examples: Administrators and Managers shall be able to access financial reports; Regular Users shall not have access.
Only users with 'Editor' role shall be able to modify data; 'Viewer' role users shall have read-only access.
correction_strategy: Explicitly specify user roles, permissions, or user types affected by the requirement.

description: Requirements that cannot be tested or verified objectively.
good_examples: The system shall respond to user interactions within 100ms, measured at the 95th percentile.
The interface shall allow users to complete the primary task (user registration) in 3 clicks or fewer, as measured in usability testing.
correction_strategy: Convert subjective qualities into measurable, testable criteria with specific metrics or acceptance tests.
